fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-10048].
  {panel}

A page content that has the following markup (with special characters):
{noformat}
test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ

_test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ_ 

*test ÁRVÍZTŰRŐ* 
{noformat}

Following the steps suggested in the following documentation resolve the character problems when exported to PDF format (installed the verdana.ttf):
* http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Create+PDF+in+another+language

However, the bold and italic fonts does not take effect (see screenshot: result1.pdf). Installing the {{Verdana Bold}} instead later, would change all the fonts in *bold* form when coverting to PDF instead (see screenshot: result2.pdf). 
It appears that the {{fop.xml}} only takes up one font at a time even if there are multiple fonts format(see screenshot: result3.jpg) being installed:
{noformat}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

<fop>
  <renderers>
    <renderer mime="application/pdf">
      <fonts>
        <font metrics-url="file:/${confluence.home}/fonts/verdanab-metrics.xml" embed-url="file:/${confluence.home}/fonts/verdanab.ttf" kerning="yes">
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="normal" weight="normal"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="normal" weight="bold"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="italic" weight="normal"/>
          <font-triplet name="verdanab" style="italic" weight="bold"/>
        </font>
      </fonts>
    </renderer>
  </renderers>
</fop>
{noformat}
fields.summary: Only a single style of custom font is supported for PDF export

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-10030].
  {panel}

Most of the queries against CONTENT table use 'lower' db function for a title field. The goes for (space) key field in SPACES table. 
We do it to make a case insensitive comparison, however it means that db2 does not use the existing indexes for those fields and performs a full table scan.
This results in a poor performance. 

This can be applicable to other database too, but it is not verified. Also other databases may have global 'case sensitivity' flag.
fields.summary: db2: queries that use 'lower' do not use index because of case sensitivity

fields.description:
Confluence now has a "submit support request" feature, whereby it submits an email with the user's question, and all the system info to help diagnosis. This system info include the following about the database:

{noformat}
        Database Dialect: net.sf.hibernate.dialect.HSQLDialect
        Database Connection URL: jdbc:hsqldb:/Users/pcurren/Atlassian/data/confluence/trunk/database/confluencedb
        Database Driver Name: org.hsqldb.jdbcDriver
        Database Driver Version: 1.8
        Database connection transaction isolation: None
{noformat}

It would be nice if this also included the actual database version. Sometimes we really need to know if they're using Oracle 9 or 10, and it's generally useful to know when, eg. customers stop using old versions of databases (eg. MySQL 4.0).

From JDBC one can obtain both the database version and JDBC driver version. Eg (from a JIRA auto-support-request):

{noformat}
    Database version: 5.0.32-Debian_7etch1-log
    Database JNDI address: java:comp/env/jdbc/JiraDS
    Database driver: MySQL-AB JDBC Driver mysql-connector-java-5.0.5 ( $Date: 2007-03-01 00:01:06 +0100 (Thu, 01 Mar 2007) $, $Revision: 6329 $ )
{noformat}
fields.summary: Include JDBC database info in automatic support request email

fields.description:
Our confluence showed slow down recently. apache had large numbers of thread sitting in a writing state with no update being sent to the client.

We did a thread dump and noticed large numbers of the following messages:

...

"TP-Processor274" daemon prio=1 tid=0x0000002ba288e1b0 nid=0x506b waiting for monitor entry [0x0000000054d9a000..0x0000000054d9dd30]
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.BoundedLinkedQueue.put(BoundedLinkedQueue.java:298)
        - waiting to lock <0x0000002aa64d8018> (a java.lang.Object)
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.QueuedExecutor.execute(QueuedExecutor.java:158)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.addTask(UsageEventListener.java:63)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.handleEvent(UsageEventListener.java:51)

...

"TP-Processor222" daemon prio=1 tid=0x0000002b9fb2a820 nid=0x4a9b waiting for monitor entry [0x0000000051c69000..0x0000000051c6cbb0]
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.BoundedLinkedQueue.put(BoundedLinkedQueue.java:298)
        - waiting to lock <0x0000002aa64d8018> (a java.lang.Object)
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.QueuedExecutor.execute(QueuedExecutor.java:158)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.addTask(UsageEventListener.java:63)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.handleEvent(UsageEventListener.java:51)

...

"TP-Processor221" daemon prio=1 tid=0x0000002ba1844f30 nid=0x4a9a waiting for monitor entry [0x0000000051b68000..0x0000000051b6bb30]
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.BoundedLinkedQueue.put(BoundedLinkedQueue.java:298)
        - waiting to lock <0x0000002aa64d8018> (a java.lang.Object)
        at EDU.oswego.cs.dl.util.concurrent.QueuedExecutor.execute(QueuedExecutor.java:158)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.addTask(UsageEventListener.java:63)
        at com.atlassian.confluence.ext.usage.event.UsageEventListener.handleEvent(UsageEventListener.java:51)
...

Recurrance of UsageEventListener class leads us to Usage Tracking Plugin.

We noticed our Usage Tracking Plugin is shown as "Outdated".
Installed Version: 0.5
Latest Version: 0.7.2

Once we disabled the plugin.  Confluence performance started getting back to normal.

It seems Outdated Usage Tracking Plugin caused locking issues.
fields.summary: Usage tracking plugin cause locking issues and slow down system

fields.description:
From a comment on CONF-1502:

"We are using a frontend Apache.
The problem was that we switched on caching in that instance which was a major mistake.
The problem was that by default the Key for caching is the URL, and this URL does not contain the user information. So instead of debugging the caching and adding the right cookies to "Vary" on it we just switched off caching."

This issue was really hard to track down, as evidenced by the fact that I only now know, three years later, why it happened. We should probably warn against using Apache caching (and mod_disk_cache) in our "setting up Confluence behind mod_proxy" documentation, and include a link to the issue:

   http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Using+Apache+with+mod_proxy
   http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/DOC/Using+Apache+with+virtual+hosts+and+mod_proxy
fields.summary: Warn against using caching in apache mod_proxy setup

fields.description:
In Confluence 2.6.1-

* Create a new news post
* Save the news post (with a title)
* Edit the news post
* Delete the title
* Save the news post

You should be taken to the View tab of the News item.
The News item's title will appear as:   $helper.page.title
On the News tab, it will appear as $blog.title.

I have replicated this in Atlassian's Test Space:  http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/OIZRBg

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9981].
  {panel}

Steps to reproduce:
1. Copy a page
2. Attach an image
3. Click cancel

fields.summary: Corrupt profile after upgrade

fields.description:
You need unique header names in each header level or the toc link leads to the first occurence of this header name.

If you have a header structure like this:

1. text1
  a. subtext1
  b. subtext2
2. text2
  a. subtext1
  b. subtext2
...

a click on 2.a or 2.b (etc.) leads to the first appearance of this header text (2a->1a;2b->1b).
So in this example you are not able to get the link 2.a. working in the toc if you do not change its header name to a unique one.
fields.summary: table of content macro: links do not include parent headers -> equal named headers in the same header level lead to incorrect linking in toc

fields.description: User experiences that  that when attaching an interlaced gifs as thumbnail,  the generated thumbnails for interlaced gifs are broken, i.e. completely  black. However If I  the source image is changed to non-interlaced Gif, thumbnails are generated fine.
fields.summary: Thumbnails for interlaced gifs are broken

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9976].
  {panel}

The {{attachment macro}} being defined in a comment is not supported in the Confluence. Defining attachment macro in a page comment would lead to stack trace generated. This would avoid users from accessing the page. Customer think that Confluence should consider a more gracefull error handling. Maybe it is possible to inhibit the rendering of an errouneus macro.

fields.description:
After a Confluence crash (see Jira issue CSP-12185) or normal application restart Confluence won't come up but dies with the attached stack trace.  The trace I'm sending is a snapshot from the logs, it shows the application starting then getting an X windows error on line 560 that I believe is normal and then the real error starting on line 918.  

I don't know if that class cast exception is a red herring or the real problem.  As this code has worked without problem on many other systems I'm pretty sure it's the former but am open to any ideas.  Anyway what we do is leave the application up and then just blindly touch a JAR or class file to force a hot reload of the application.  After doing this one or more times (some times many more) Confluence comes up and runs well (until the next out of memory error, but that's the other problem at CSP 12185).
fields.summary: Confluence won't restart reliably

fields.description:
Following through the instructions given in the following link doesn't really enable the macro library (macros.vm) to reload automatically.

* http://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=137633

Instructions:
Perform the following modifications before starting the server, or restart it afterwards:

# Edit ./confluence/src/etc/java/velocity.properties (or /WEB-INF/classes/velocity.properties if you are using the webapp).
# Set all the "...resource.loader.cache" values to false.
# Set the "class.resource.loader.cache" to false.
# Set "velocimacro.library.autoreload" to true (uncomment the line if necessary).

This has been tested in 2.3 as well and it didn't auto reload when I made changes to _macros. vm_
fields.summary: Disabling caching still requires a restart for modifications on macros.vm

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9965].
  {panel}

I'm still a relatively new Confluence user, but there are a couple of things that I've noticed:
* The most popular issue in the CONF project has 143 votes
* The top 50 issues in the CONF project have an average of ~53 votes each

According to the Sales Team's e-mail signature (incidentally the site shows different values), there are over 7000 Confluence users in over 75 countries - e.g. _the most important issue only has the vote of ~2% of the total number of Confluence instances_. I don't think it is necessarily reasonable to assume that the views of 2% are truly representative of the majority - especially since there appears to be a far greater proportion of technical users than any other type of user logging/commenting on issues.

This is concerning to me considering Atlassian use these votes to determine the order in which issues/feature requests are addressed - e.g. *major product decisions are being made based on very little data*. A good analogy would be a movie studio - they wouldn't decide to make a sequel after reading a couple of critics' reviews, they poll millions of peoples' opinions by counting ticket sales. I definitely think effort needs to be made to increase the number of votes on Confluence issues.


What I'm proposing is basically a means to:
* Vastly increase visibility of (and by proxy, voters on) Confluence-related issues
* Reduce the number of duplicate/similar issues being logged - e.g. Atlassian staff can spend less time managing the tracking system and more time working on the issues
* Reduce barriers to browsing/watching/voting so that the views of a far greater variety of users are also represented
* Make it easy for users to stay up-to-date with new issues
* Make it easier for Atlassian staff to prioritise issues effectively, since the differences in votes between issues would probably be greatly exaggerated rather than 1-10 votes

Essentially what I'd like to see is a sort of 'Dashboard' added to the Global Administration Console - preferably on the 99% empty _console.action_ page. This 'Dashboard' would basically be a hybrid between Confluence's main Dashboard & the Plugin Repository, and display things like:
* The 10-20 most recently logged issues
* The 10-20 most recently updated issues
* Watched issues
* Voted issues

Similar to the plugin repository, each item should have drill-down capabilities to see a cut-down version of the corresponding JIRA issues page (e.g. details/comments/status with simple actions such as vote/watch).

To prevent multiple people from a single site/instance voting on issues, a JIRA account could automatically be created based on the Server ID (or other uniquely identifying data) - e.g. each admin would share a common view.

This is just a starting point - I'd be keen/happy to be involved with the planning of this feature from a design/functionality perspective (don't ask me to code anything though :) ).
fields.summary: 'Dashboard' in Global Administration Console for JIRA issues in the 'CONF' project

fields.description:
Two customers have encountered this problem. CSP-5178 and CSP-12970. 
It appears when trying to upgrade from 2.2.10 or prior straight to 2.6, 2.6 does not realise that this version does not have a bandana table and does not try to create it. 
To workaround this issue, customers have to upgrade to 2.5 which will create the table then upgrade to 2.6. 
I have provided the mysql backup and home directory as given to me by the customer. 
Steps to reproduce
1) Install confluence 2.2.9 standalone. 
2) Unzip the home directory (\\DEVFILES\Partha\Cases\CSP-5178\confluence.tar)to a location and point the standalone there. 
3) Unzip the mysql backup (\\DEVFILES\Partha\Cases\CSP-5178\bkup.sql.gz) and import into mysql (Command to import looks like this, change names as necessary: mysql -u username -ppassword database_name < FILE.sql)
4) Modify the confluence.cfg.xml file to point to your imported db.
5) Start confluence and check that it works and you can browse pages. 
6) Stop confluence
7) Install 2.6 and point to the old home directory 
8) Start confluence. You should see table doesn't exist errors.
fields.summary: Cannot upgrade from 2.2.10 and earlier to 2.6 without first having to upgrade to 2.5

fields.description:
There are several problems with wrapping in the Attachments and Attachments macros.  Comments always wrap properly on spaces, but other potentially long columns (e.g. Name, creator) do not.  

So, if any attachment on the page has a long file name, and/or if the creator has been extended by a subsequent modification (which adds the words "modified by [users]"), the comments column becomes squeezed to its smallest possible width (a single long word).  This is of course ironic and problemmatic since the comments column often has the most actual information.

The Attachments tab and the Attachments macro should be fixed as follows:
  1. the Name (i.e. file name) column should dynamically wrap at spaces or dashes.  
  2. The Creator column should dynamically wrap at the point where  "modified by [user]" is added.  If possible, it should also wrap between first and last name and between last hame and any descriptive parethetic in the name (such as is used by [Atlassian].)

(Note: that attachment macro does not display the "modified by [user]" feature - a bug that should be fixed.)

If these two columns begin to dynamically wrap, then the comments column will have more room to display its text.
fields.summary: Wrapping Doesn't Work Properly in Attachments Tab and the Attachment Macros

fields.description:
This is reported by Scott.

The problem is in the number of attachments which is shown in brackets on the attachments tab. For a short period after adding a new attachment, this was continuing to show 0 for a particular page.

A few minutes later it was correctly showing 1. Is this number generated from a search? That is to say, is it relying on indexing? If so it would be more accurate if it was a DB query.

Currently it appears that every time an attachment is uploaded, there is a good chance the displayed number will be wrong for a short period.
fields.summary: The attachments tab temporarily shows the wrong number of attachments

fields.description:
Each request should have a timestamp attached to it by a filter that processes each request.

The timestamp should be accessible to Confluence via a thread-local and a request attribute. Operations which are concerned about exact timings should use this timestamp rather than creating a new date or checking System.currentTimeMillis.

The timestamp should be accessible to web interface clients as a response header and an HTML meta tag.
fields.summary: Filter and thread-local for "request timestamp"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9939].
  {panel}

Currently user need to save in order to preview.

The RTE could be launched with checkbox to indicate whether save as a new version or not.
If the document is edited by the same person within a time period, then the save as new version is unchecked by default.
If the document is updated by another user, then the save as new version is checked and cannot be modified.

The set notification (minor changes) can follow this concept too.
fields.summary: Allow users to specify whether to create new versions or overwrite same version

fields.description:
From a heap dump we got on an out of memory error, it is quite clear that the GzipFilter is creating very large GzipResponseStream objects.  The large part of the GzipResponseStream is its "baos" output stream field. One might expect these streams to be bounded in such a way that they would not be very large, but I had 4 streams over 50MB in size and 1 of those was 100MB.  

The heap dump did not include urls for most of them, but the largest request was to download a large, already compressed, attachment from Confluence.  If we cannot set a smaller bound on the size of the GzipResponseStream, we should at least be able to stop using it for downloading already compressed attachments.


A possible immediate workaround for anybody finding this problem is to remove or modify the gzip filter mapping in the web.xml:
{code:type=xml}
    <filter-mapping>
        <filter-name>gzipFilter</filter-name>
        <url-pattern>/*</url-pattern>
    </filter-mapping>
{code}
Such a workaround would likely have other, negative performance side-affects, but they may be preferable.
fields.summary: Gzip filter (used for http-compression between client and server) creates very large temporary objects in memory

fields.description:
It is currently impossible for macros which have a body that contains wiki markup to be correctly rendered or converted when switching between RichText and wiki markup editing. For example, the \{toc-zone} macro generates a table of contents for all headings contained within it's body. However, when it's contents are viewed in the RTE bad stuff happens. Here are the options, with all possible combinations of the 'supressMacroRenderingDuringyWysiwyg' ('Macro Rendering') and 'suppressSurroundingTagDuringWysiwygRendering' ('Surrounding Tag') methods:

|| Suppress Macro Rendering || Suppress Surrounding Tag || Result ||
| false | false |  {color:red}All content is *unrendered*{color} and {color:green}wiki markup for the \{toc-zone} is displayed{color}. Eg. 'h1.' displays as 'h1.', not a pretty heading. Not what I would expect. |
| true | false | {color:green}All content is unrendered{color} and {color:green} wiki markup for the \{toc-zone} is displayed{color}. |
| true | true | {color:red}All content is *rendered*{color} and {color:green}wiki markup for the \{toc-zone} is suppressed{color}. Additionally, once you switch to and from RTE mode, or save, the original \{toc-zone} markup is lost, and will no longer dynamically update. Not only that, but the hard-coded markup will loose it's links also. Not exactly what I had in mind. |
| false | true | {color:green}All content is *rendered*{color} and {color:green}wiki markup for the \{toc-zone} is suppressed{color}. However, as above, switching between RTE and wiki mode will corrupt the page irretrievably. |

Essentially, it seems that the 'Suppress Macro Rendering' option is not working as expected - it seems that 'Suppress Surrounding Tag' is the only flag which has any effect, and when enabled it will do both - either display the markup for everything or display the markup for nothing.

In any case, I think that a better option would be to allow an option for macros to specify that the macro *body* to be rendered, rather than the whole macro. Some cases will still want the exiting options (if they actually worked, that is), but in the example of \{toc-zone} it would be much more useful to be able to display the {toc-zone} macro itself, but have it's body markup rendered as per usual. As such, perhaps an extra option to 'suppressMacroBodyRenderingInWysywiyg' could be added, which will be trumped if the 'suppressMacroRenderingInWysiwiy' returns true.

But even if that is not added, getting the other two flags to work correctly would help a lot...
fields.summary: Rich Text Editor handling of macros with body markup is buggy and/or incomplete

fields.description: If you have any <tag> elements in your wiki markup, which would be expected to be rendered directly as seen, not as HTML, they disappear when you switch to the RTE. I expect that this is due to the wiki content not being HTML-escaped correctly in the conversion process, so the RTE thinks the content is a real tag.
fields.summary: WIki markup containing <tag> elements is erased when switching to the RTE

fields.description:
Personal spaces are not searched using the "quick search" facility.  Personal spaces should be included in the search, or at least configurable to include in the search.  We have a lot of people using Personal spaces, for personal blogs, and the content in those blogs is something we want accessible in quick search.

We consider this a major feature, because it is not "obvious" to the user that this is the problem (personal spaces not included).

Please see CSP-13045 for more information.
fields.summary: Personal Spaces should be included (or configurable to include) in quick search

fields.description:
When the user renames or moves a page, Confluence updates the links all pages that link to that page.

Please change the automated linking update so that it is classified as a minor edit of the page. Otherwise, any user who is watching the page with the link-rewrites receives a notification, when the semantic content of the watched page has not changed at all.
fields.summary: Do not send notifications when page links change because of page movement

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *Confluence Server*. Using *Confluence Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONFCLOUD-9924].
  {panel}

When copying and pasting double hyphens from Microsoft Word into the Rich Text editor, Confluence always converts them into strike-through text rather than em-dashes or en-dashes.

For example, if you type this in Word:
This text\-\-if you can imagine\-\-is an example of em-dashes.
Then Word converts the double-hyphens into em-dashes (because the user did not put spaces on either side of the hyphens).

But, if you copy the text from Word into Confluence, then Confluence automatically converts the text into strike-through text:
This text -if you can imagine- is an example of em-dashes.

Please interpret double-hyphens first, before looking for strike-through text. In this way, parenthetical statements copied from Word will be shown with en-dashes rather than strike-through text.
fields.summary: Always interpret double-hyphens as en-dashes, and never strikethroughs
